description: Sweet, dense, and flavorful deep-fried pancakes made from a batter of mashed ripe bananas and flour. A classic Ugandan tea-time snack with a uniquely soft and cake-like interior and a crispy, golden-brown exterior.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Kabalagala are a beloved traditional snack, deeply associated with the Buganda kingdom and other banana-growing regions. They are a common sight in local markets and are a popular way to use up overripe bananas. The name itself is specific to this distinct banana fritter, often enjoyed with a cup of black tea in the afternoon.

ingredients.name: Very Ripe Bananas
ingredients.notes: The skin should be yellow with many black spots. They must be ripe for sweetness and flavor.

ingredients.name: Sugar
ingredients.notes: Adjust to taste, depending on the sweetness of the bananas

ingredients.name: Water or Milk
ingredients.notes: As needed to achieve a thick, droppable batter

steps.instruction: Peel the very ripe bananas and place them in a mixing bowl. Mash them thoroughly with a fork or masher until you have a smooth paste with no large lumps.
Add the sugar, salt, and optional cardamom powder to the mashed bananas. Mix well.

Gradually add the flour to the banana mixture, stirring continuously to form a thick batter. The batter should be thick enough to hold its shape but still be droppable from a spoon. If it's too stiff, add a little water or milk, one tablespoon at a time.
Heat the oil in a deep pot over medium heat until moderately hot (around 160-170°C / 320-340°F). The oil is ready when a small drop of batter sizzles and rises to the surface.
Using a tablespoon, carefully drop spoonfuls of the batter into the hot oil. Do not overcrowd the pot; fry in batches.
Fry the kabalagala for 3-4 minutes on each side, turning once, until they are puffed up and a deep golden brown on all sides.

cooking_indicators.visual: Deep golden brown and puffed up
cooking_indicators.texture: Crispy exterior, soft and cooked through inside.

steps.instruction: Use a slotted spoon to remove the kabalagala from the oil, allowing excess oil to drain back into the pot.
Transfer them to a plate lined with paper towels to absorb any extra oil.
Serve the kabalagala warm or at room temperature.

serving_suggestions: Best enjoyed fresh with a cup of black tea or coffee. They can be eaten plain or with a drizzle of honey for extra sweetness.
